</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Set forth below is additional information with respect to Toyota&#146;s material plans to construct,
	expand or improve its facilities.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%;PADDING-BOTTOM:0PX; ">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Toyota completed annual production capacity increase at its Argentina
	factory from 90 thousand units to 140 thousand units at the end of 2015, and at its Sorocaba Plant in Brazil from 70 thousand units to 110 thousand units in January 2016.
</FONT>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="1">
<SUP STYLE="VERTICAL-ALIGN:BASELINE; POSITION:RELATIVE; BOTTOM:.8EX">
</SUP>
</FONT>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Toyota plans to increase annual production capacity in Turkey from 150 thousand units to 280 thousand units beginning at
	the end of 2016, to build a new plant in Mexico in 2019 and to launch a third plant in Guangzhou in China in 2018.
</FONT>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="1">
<SUP STYLE="VERTICAL-ALIGN:BASELINE; POSITION:RELATIVE; BOTTOM:.8EX">
</SUP>
</FONT>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Tianjin FAW Toyota Motor Co., Ltd. also plans to construct a new production line to replace an aging existing line in the middle of 2018. At the beginning of 2019, Toyota plans to
	launch a new plant in Malaysia dedicated to passenger vehicles with annual production capacity of 50,000 cars.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	To enhance
	production capacity of auto parts, Toyota constructed a plant for hybrid vehicle battery production in China in September 2015 and a plant for passenger vehicle engine production in Indonesia and Brazil in February 2016.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Toyota does not collect information on the amount of expenditures already paid for each plant under construction because Toyota believes
	that it is difficult and it would require unreasonable effort or expense to identify and categorize each expenditure item with reasonable accuracy as past and future expenditures. Toyota&#146;s construction projects consist of numerous expenditures,
	each of which is continually being adjusted and incurred in variable and constantly changing amounts as part of the overall work-in-progress.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Seasonality
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Toyota does
	not consider its seasonality material in the sense of significantly higher sales during any certain period of the year as compared to other periods of the year.
</FONT>
</P>
<EFX_LEGAL_PROCEEDINGS>
<A NAME="FIS_LEGAL_PROCEEDINGS"></A>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Legal Proceedings
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	From time-to-time, Toyota issues vehicle recalls and
	takes other safety measures including safety campaigns relating to its vehicles. Since 2009, Toyota issued safety campaigns related to the risk of floor mat entrapment of
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	50
</FONT>
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage56"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D19734D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	accelerator pedals and vehicle recalls related to slow-to-return or sticky accelerator pedals. In March 2014, Toyota entered into a Deferred Prosecution Agreement (&#147;DPA&#148;) to resolve an
	investigation by the U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of New York (&#147;SDNY&#148;) related to unintended acceleration in certain of its vehicles. The DPA provides for an independent monitor to review and assess policies and procedures
	relating to Toyota&#146;s safety communications process, its process for sharing vehicle accident information internally and its process for preparing and sharing certain technical reports.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	In 2010, there was a recall related to the software program that controls the antilock braking system in certain models, including the
	Prius, which led to putative class action lawsuits on behalf of owners of recalled vehicles and owners of vehicles which were not recalled. The United States District Court for the Central District of California denied the plaintiffs&#146; motions
	for class certification and granted summary judgment in Toyota&#146;s favor denying the plaintiffs&#146; claims related to both the recalled vehicles and the non-recalled vehicles. Proceedings involving the recalled vehicles have concluded; the
	appeals of the granting of summary judgment and the denial of class certification of the claims for the non-recalled vehicles are still pending.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Personal injury and wrongful death claims involving allegations of unintended acceleration are pending in several consolidated proceedings in federal and state courts, as well as in individual cases in
	various other states. The judges in the consolidated federal action and the consolidated California state action have approved an Intensive Settlement Process (&#147;ISP&#148;) for such claims in those actions. Under the ISP, all individual claims
	within the consolidated actions are stayed pending completion of a process to assess whether they can be resolved on terms acceptable to the parties. Cases not resolved after completion of the ISP will then proceed to discovery and toward trial.
	Toyota has offered the ISP process to plaintiffs in other consolidated actions and in individual cases, as well.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Toyota has
	been named as a defendant in 33 economic loss class action lawsuits, which, together with similar lawsuits against Takata and other automakers, have been made part of a multi-district litigation proceeding in the United States District Court for the
	Southern District of Florida, arising out of allegations that airbag inflators manufactured by Takata are defective. These lawsuits are at an early stage.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Toyota has received a request for information from the SDNY related to statements concerning one or more reported injuries sustained in Toyota vehicles following deployments of Takata airbags.&nbsp;Toyota
	is cooperating with the request.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Toyota self-reported a process gap in fulfilling certain emissions defect information
	reporting requirements with the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (&#147;EPA&#148;) and California Air Resources Board, including updates on its repair completion rates for recalled emissions components and certain other reports concerning
	emissions related defects. Toyota is involved in discussions with these agencies. The SDNY and EPA have requested certain follow-up information regarding this reporting issue, and Toyota is cooperating with the request.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Toyota also has various other pending legal actions and claims, including without limitation personal injury and wrongful death lawsuits
	and claims in the United States, and is subject to government investigations
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	from-time-to-time.
</FONT>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Beyond the amounts accrued with respect to all aforementioned matters, Toyota is unable to estimate a range of reasonably possible loss, if any, for the pending legal matters because (i) many of the
	proceedings are in evidence gathering stages, (ii) significant factual issues need to be resolved, (iii) the legal theory or nature of the claims is unclear, (iv) the outcome of future motions or appeals is unknown and/or (v) the outcomes of other
	matters of these types vary widely and do not appear sufficiently similar to offer meaningful guidance. Based upon information currently available to Toyota, however, Toyota believes that its losses from these matters, if any, beyond the amounts
	accrued, would not have a material adverse effect on Toyota&#146;s financial position, results of operations or cash flows.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	51
</FONT>
</P>

<EFX_BENEFICIAL_OWNERS>
<A NAME="FIS_BENEFICIAL_OWNERS"></A>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<A NAME="D19734D20F_HTM_ROM19734_11">
</A>
	4.C ORGANIZATIONAL STRUCTURE
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	As of March&nbsp;31, 2016, Toyota Motor Corporation had 257 Japanese subsidiaries and 291 overseas subsidiaries. The following table sets
	forth for each of Toyota Motor Corporation&#146;s principal subsidiaries, the country of incorporation and the percentage ownership interest and the voting interest held by Toyota Motor Corporation.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
	&nbsp;

<A NAME="eolPage58"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D19734D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<A NAME="D19734D20F_HTM_ROM19734_12">
</A>
	4.D PROPERTY, PLANTS AND EQUIPMENT
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	As of March&nbsp;31, 2016, Toyota and its affiliated companies produced automobiles and related components through more than 50 overseas
	manufacturing organizations in 28 countries and regions besides Japan. The facilities are located principally in Japan, the United States, Canada, the United Kingdom, France, Turkey, Thailand, China, Taiwan, India, Indonesia, South Africa,
	Australia, Argentina and Brazil.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	In addition to its manufacturing facilities, Toyota&#146;s properties include sales offices
	and other sales facilities in major cities, repair service facilities and research and development facilities.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The following
	table sets forth information, as of March&nbsp;31, 2016, with respect to Toyota&#146;s principal facilities and organizations, all of which are owned by Toyota Motor Corporation or its subsidiaries. However, small portions, all under approximately
	20%, of some facilities are on leased premises.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>

<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	53
</FONT>
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage59"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D19734D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Toyota is constantly engaged in upgrading, modernizing and revamping the operations of its
	manufacturing facilities based on its assessment of market needs and prospects. To respond flexibly to fluctuations in demand in each of its production operations throughout the world, Toyota continually reviews and implements appropriate production
	measures such as revising takt time and adjusting days of operation. As a result, Toyota believes it would require unreasonable effort to track the exact productive capacity and the extent of utilization of each of its manufacturing facilities with
	a reasonable degree of accuracy.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	As of March&nbsp;31, 2016, property, plant and equipment having a net book value of
	approximately &yen;335.3&nbsp;billion was pledged as collateral securing indebtedness incurred by Toyota Motor Corporation&#146;s consolidated subsidiaries. Toyota believes that there does not exist any material environmental issues that may affect
	the company&#146;s utilization of its assets.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Toyota considers all its principal manufacturing facilities and other
	significant properties to be in good condition and adequate to meet the needs of its operations.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	See &#147;&#151; Business
	Overview &#151; Capital Expenditures and Divestitures&#148; for a description of Toyota&#146;s material plans to construct, expand or improve facilities.
</FONT>
</P>
</EFX_COMPANY_INFORMATION>

	ITEM&nbsp;4A. UNRESOLVED STAFF COMMENTS

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">

</FONT>

<EFX_OPERATING_AND_FINANCIAL_REVIEW>
<A NAME="FIS_OPERATING_AND_FINANCIAL_REVIEW"></A>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<A NAME="D19734D20F_HTM_ROM19734_14">
</A>
	ITEM&nbsp;5. OPERATING AND FINANCIAL REVIEW AND PROSPECTS
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<A NAME="D19734D20F_HTM_ROM19734_15">
</A>
	5.A OPERATING RESULTS
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<I>
	Financial information discussed in this section is derived from Toyota&#146;s consolidated financial statements that appear elsewhere in this annual report. The financial statements have been prepared
	in conformity with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America.
</I>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Overview
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The business segments of Toyota include automotive operations, financial services operations and all other operations. Automotive
	operations are Toyota&#146;s most significant business segment, accounting for 89% of Toyota&#146;s total revenues before the elimination of intersegment revenues for fiscal 2016. Toyota&#146;s primary markets based on vehicle unit sales for fiscal
	2016 were: Japan (24%), North America (33%), Europe (10%)&nbsp;and Asia (15%).
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	Automotive Market Environment
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The worldwide automotive market is highly competitive and volatile. The demand for automobiles is affected by a number of factors
	including social, political and general economic conditions; introduction of new vehicles and technologies; and costs incurred by customers to purchase or operate vehicles. These factors can cause consumer demand to vary substantially in different
	geographic markets and for different types of automobiles.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	During fiscal 2016, although markets have progressed in a steady
	manner, especially in the U.S., markets in some emerging countries have become stagnant, and the Japanese market has slowed down mainly in the sales of mini-vehicles due to the tax increase. Meanwhile, the development of automated driving
	technology, as well as efforts toward improvement in environmental friendliness and safety, has made significant progress.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	54
</FONT>
</P>

<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:8PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:2PX;BORDER-BOTTOM:0.5PT SOLID #000000;WIDTH:10%">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	*
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#147;Other&#148; consists of Central and South America, Oceania, Africa and the Middle East, etc.
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	In each of fiscal 2015 and fiscal 2016, during which the market in Japan experienced downturns, Toyota&#146;s consolidated vehicle unit
	sales in Japan decreased compared to the previous fiscal year. Through the efforts of dealers nationwide, for fiscal 2015 and fiscal 2016, the Toyota and Lexus brands&#146; market share excluding
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	mini-vehicles
</FONT>
	was 46.0% and 46.8%, and the market share (including Daihatsu and Hino brands) including
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	mini-vehicles
</FONT>
	was 41.8% and 43.2%, each remaining at a high level, as was the case in fiscal 2014. Overseas consolidated
	vehicle unit sales increased as a whole during fiscal 2015, due to increased sales in North America and Europe, while vehicle unit sales decreased as a whole during fiscal 2016, due mainly to decreases in Asia and the Middle East, despite an
	increase in North America.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Toyota&#146;s share of total vehicle unit sales in each market is influenced by the quality,
	safety, reliability, price, design, performance, economy and utility of Toyota&#146;s vehicles compared with those offered by other manufacturers. The timely introduction of new or redesigned vehicles is also an important factor in satisfying
	customer needs. Toyota&#146;s ability to satisfy changing customer preferences can affect its revenues and earnings significantly.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The profitability of Toyota&#146;s automotive operations is affected by many factors. These factors include:
</FONT>
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	55
</FONT>
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage61"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D19734D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Changes in laws, regulations, policies and other governmental actions can also materially
	impact the profitability of Toyota&#146;s automotive operations. These laws, regulations and policies include those attributed to environmental matters, vehicle safety, fuel economy and emissions that can add significantly to the cost of vehicles.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Many governments also impose local content requirements, impose tariffs and other trade barriers, and enact price or exchange
	controls that can limit an automaker&#146;s operations and can make the repatriation of profits unpredictable. Changes in these laws, regulations, policies and other governmental actions may affect the production, licensing, distribution or sale of
	Toyota&#146;s products, cost of products or applicable tax rates. From time-to-time when potential safety problems arise, Toyota issues vehicle recalls and takes other safety measures including safety campaigns relating to its vehicles. Since 2009,
	Toyota issued safety campaigns related to the risk of floor mat entrapment of accelerator pedals and vehicle recalls related to slow-to-return or sticky accelerator pedals. In 2010, Toyota announced a recall related to the software program that
	controls the antilock braking system in certain models including the Prius. The recalls and other safety measures described above have led to a number of claims and lawsuits against Toyota. For a more detailed description of these claims and
	lawsuits, see &#147;Information on the Company &#151; Business Overview &#151; Legal Proceedings&#148; and note 24 to the consolidated financial statements.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The worldwide automotive industry is in a period of global competition which may continue for the foreseeable future, and in general the competitive environment in which Toyota operates is likely to
	intensify. Toyota believes it has the resources, strategies and technologies in place to compete effectively in the industry as an independent company for the foreseeable future.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	Financial Services Operations
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The competition in the worldwide
	automobile financial services industry is intensifying. As competition increases, margins on financing transactions may decrease and market share may also decline as customers obtain financing for Toyota vehicles from alternative sources.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Toyota&#146;s financial services operations mainly include loans and leasing programs for customers and dealers. Toyota
	believes that its ability to provide financing to its customers is an important value added service. Therefore, Toyota has expanded its network of finance subsidiaries in order to offer financial services in many countries.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Toyota&#146;s competitors for retail financing and retail leasing include commercial banks, credit unions and other finance companies.
	Meanwhile, commercial banks and other captive automobile finance companies also compete against Toyota&#146;s wholesale financing activities.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Toyota&#146;s total finance receivables decreased during fiscal 2016 mainly due to the unfavorable impact of fluctuations in foreign currency translation rates. Also, vehicles and equipment on operating
	leases, net increased during fiscal 2016 mainly due to an increase in the number of operating leases in financial services subsidiaries in North America.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	56
</FONT>
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Toyota&#146;s finance receivables are subject to collectability risks. These risks include consumer and
	dealer insolvencies and insufficient collateral values (less costs to sell) to realize the full carrying values of these receivables. See discussion in &#147;Critical Accounting Estimates &#151; Allowance for Doubtful Accounts and Credit
	Losses&#148; and note 10 to the consolidated financial statements.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Toyota continues to originate leases to finance new Toyota
	vehicles. These leasing activities are subject to residual value risk. Residual value losses could be incurred when the lessee of a vehicle does not exercise the option to purchase the vehicle at the end of the lease term. See discussion in
	&#147;Critical Accounting Estimates &#151; Investment in Operating Leases&#148; and note 2 to the consolidated financial statements.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Toyota enters into interest rate swap agreements and cross currency interest rate swap agreements to convert its fixed-rate debt to variable-rate functional currency debt. A portion of the derivative
	instruments are entered into to hedge interest rate risk from an economic perspective and are not designated as a hedge of specific assets or liabilities on Toyota&#146;s consolidated balance sheet and accordingly, unrealized gains or losses related
	to derivatives that are not designated as a hedge are recognized currently in operations. See discussion in &#147;Critical Accounting Estimates &#151; Derivatives and Other Contracts at Fair Value&#148; and &#147;Quantitative and Qualitative
	Disclosures about Market Risk&#148; and notes 21 and 27 to the consolidated financial statements.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The fluctuations in funding
	costs can affect the profitability of Toyota&#146;s financial services operations. Funding costs are affected by a number of factors, some of which are not in Toyota&#146;s control. These factors
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	57
</FONT>
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage63"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D19734D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	include general economic conditions, prevailing interest rates and Toyota&#146;s financial strength. Funding costs decreased during fiscal 2015 and 2016, mainly as a result of lower interest
	rates.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Toyota launched its credit card business in Japan in April 2001. As of March&nbsp;31, 2015, Toyota had
	13.5&nbsp;million cardholders, an increase of 0.8&nbsp;million cardholders compared with March&nbsp;31, 2014. As of March&nbsp;31, 2016, Toyota had 14.3&nbsp;million cardholders, an increase of 0.8&nbsp;million cardholders compared with
	March&nbsp;31, 2015. Credit card receivables as of March&nbsp;31, 2015 was &yen;380.9 billion nearly equal to March&nbsp;31, 2014, and that as of March&nbsp;31, 2016 increased by &yen;2.7 billion from March&nbsp;31, 2015 to &yen;383.6&nbsp;billion.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	Other Business Operations
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Toyota&#146;s other business operations consist of housing (including the manufacture and sale of prefabricated homes), information technology related businesses (including information technology and
	telecommunications, intelligent transport systems and GAZOO) and other businesses.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Toyota does not expect its other business
	operations to materially contribute to Toyota&#146;s consolidated results of operations.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	Currency Fluctuations
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Toyota is affected by fluctuations in foreign currency exchange rates. Toyota is exposed to fluctuations in the value of the Japanese yen
	against the U.S. dollar and the euro as well as the Australian dollar, the Russian ruble, the Canadian dollar, the British pound, and others. Toyota&#146;s consolidated financial statements, which are presented in Japanese yen, are affected by
	foreign currency exchange fluctuations through both translation risk and transaction risk.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Translation risk is the risk that
	Toyota&#146;s consolidated financial statements for a particular period or for a particular date will be affected by changes in the prevailing exchange rates of the currencies in those countries in which Toyota does business compared with the
	Japanese yen. Even though the fluctuations of currency exchange rates to the Japanese yen can be substantial, and, therefore, significantly impact comparisons with prior periods and among the various geographic markets, the translation risk is a
	reporting consideration and does not reflect Toyota&#146;s underlying results of operations. Toyota does not hedge against translation risk.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Transaction risk is the risk that the currency structure of Toyota&#146;s costs and liabilities will deviate from the currency structure of sales proceeds and assets. Transaction risk relates primarily to
	sales proceeds from Toyota&#146;s non-domestic operations from vehicles produced in Japan.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Toyota believes that the location
	of its production facilities in different parts of the world has significantly reduced the level of transaction risk. As part of its globalization strategy, Toyota has continued to localize production by constructing production facilities in the
	major markets in which it sells its vehicles. In calendar 2014 and 2015, Toyota produced 76.5% and 75.1%, respectively, of its non-domestic sales outside Japan. In North America, 74.4% and 72.2% of vehicles sold in calendar 2014 and 2015,
	respectively, were produced locally. In Europe, 73.7% and 76.3% of vehicles sold in calendar 2014 and 2015, respectively, were produced locally. Localizing production enables Toyota to locally purchase many of the supplies and resources used in the
	production process, which allows for a better match of local currency revenues with local currency expenses.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Toyota also
	enters into foreign currency transactions and other hedging instruments to address a portion of its transaction risk. This has reduced, but not eliminated, the effects of foreign currency exchange rate fluctuations, which in some years can be
	significant. See notes 21 and 27 to the consolidated financial statements for additional information.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	58
</FONT>
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage64"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D19734D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Generally, a weakening of the Japanese yen against other currencies has a positive effect on
	Toyota&#146;s revenues, operating income and net income attributable to Toyota Motor Corporation. A strengthening of the Japanese yen against other currencies has the opposite effect. In each of fiscal 2015 and 2016, the Japanese yen was on average
	weaker against the U.S. dollar in comparison to the previous fiscal year. The Japanese yen was at the end of fiscal 2015 weaker against the U.S. dollar in comparison to the end of fiscal 2014, but was at the end of fiscal 2016 stronger against the
	U.S. dollar in comparison to the end of fiscal 2015. In fiscal 2015, the Japanese yen was on average weaker against the euro in comparison to fiscal 2014, but in fiscal 2016, was on average stronger against the euro in comparison to fiscal 2015. At
	the end of each of fiscal 2015 and 2016, the Japanese yen was stronger against the euro in comparison to the end of the previous fiscal year. See further discussion in &#147;Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures about Market Risk &#151; Market
	Risk Disclosures &#151; Foreign Currency Exchange Rate Risk&#148;.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	During fiscal 2015 and 2016, the average exchange rate of
	the Japanese yen against the U.S. dollar and the euro compared to the previous fiscal year fluctuated as described above. The operating results excluding the impact of currency fluctuations described in &#147;Results of Operations &#151; Fiscal 2016
	Compared with Fiscal 2015&#148; and &#147;Results of Operations &#151; Fiscal 2015 Compared with Fiscal 2014&#148; show results of net revenues obtained by applying the Japanese yen&#146;s average exchange rate in the previous fiscal year to the
	local currency-denominated net revenues for fiscal 2015 and 2016, respectively, as if the value of the Japanese yen had remained constant for the comparable periods. Results excluding the impact of currency fluctuations year-on-year are not on the
	same basis as Toyota&#146;s consolidated financial statements and do not conform with U.S. GAAP. Furthermore, Toyota does not believe that these measures are a substitute for U.S. GAAP measures. However, Toyota believes that such results excluding
	the impact of currency fluctuations year-on-year provide additional useful information to investors regarding the operating performance on a local currency basis.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	Segmentation
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Toyota&#146;s most significant business segment is its
	automotive operations. Toyota carries out its automotive operations as a global competitor in the worldwide automotive market. Management allocates resources to, and assesses the performance of, its automotive operations as a single business segment
	on a worldwide basis. Toyota does not manage any subset of its automotive operations, such as domestic or overseas operations or parts, as separate management units.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The management of the automotive operations is organized by function, with a manager having oversight responsibility for each function within the segment. Management assesses financial and non-financial
	data such as vehicle unit sales, production volume, market share information, vehicle model plans and plant location costs to allocate resources within the automotive operations.
</FONT>
</P>

<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D19734D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>

<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	*
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#147;Other&#148; consists of Central and South America, Oceania, Africa and the Middle East.
</FONT>
</TD>

</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	Net Revenues
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Toyota had net revenues for fiscal 2016 of
	&yen;28,403.1 billion, an increase of &yen;1,168.5 billion, or 4.3%, compared with the prior fiscal year. This increase mainly reflected the favorable impact of fluctuations in foreign currency translation rates of &yen;386.4 billion and changes in
	vehicle unit sales and sales mix of &yen;330.0 billion. Excluding the impact of changes in the Japanese yen values used for translation purposes of &yen;386.4 billion, net revenues would have been &yen;28,016.6 billion during fiscal 2016, a 2.9%
	increase compared with the prior fiscal year. The North America automotive market increased by 6.2% in calendar 2015 compared with the prior calendar year due to the market in the U.S. progressing in a steady manner. However, Toyota&#146;s
	consolidated vehicle unit sales decreased in Japan due mainly to the slowdown of the mini-vehicles market, in Asia due mainly to the heating up of the competitive climate as well as a market downturn, and in the Middle East, Africa and Central and
	South America due mainly to the fall in demand resulting from the low price of crude oil and currency weakness. Under these automotive market conditions, Toyota&#146;s consolidated vehicle unit sales decreased by 3.2% compared with the prior fiscal
	year to 8,681&nbsp;thousand vehicles.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	60
</FONT>
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Toyota&#146;s net revenues include net revenues from sales of products, consisting of net revenues from
	automotive operations and all other operations, which increased by 3.7% during fiscal 2016 compared with the prior fiscal year to &yen;26,549.1 billion, and net revenues from financial services operations which increased by 14.3% during fiscal 2016
	compared with the prior fiscal year to &yen;1,854.0 billion. Excluding the impact of changes in the Japanese yen values used for translation purposes of &yen;311.9 billion, net revenues from sales of products would have been &yen;26,237.1 billion
	during fiscal 2016, a 2.4% increase compared with the prior fiscal year. The increase in net revenues from sales of products is mainly due to changes in vehicle unit sales and sales mix. Excluding the impact of changes in the Japanese yen values
	used for translation purposes of &yen;74.5 billion, net revenues from financial services operations would have been &yen;1,779.4 billion during fiscal 2016, a 9.7% increase compared with the prior fiscal year.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The following table shows the number of financing contracts by geographic region at the end of fiscal 2016 and 2015, respectively.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>

<TR>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	*
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#147;Other&#148; consists of Central and South America, Oceania and Africa.
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Geographically, net revenues (before the elimination of intersegment revenues) for fiscal 2016 increased by 2.5% in Japan, 14.2% in North America, and 0.5% in Asia, whereas net revenues decreased by 6.6%
	in Europe, and 9.8% in Other compared with the prior fiscal year. Excluding the impact of changes in the Japanese yen values used for translation purposes of &yen;386.4 billion, net revenues in fiscal 2016 would have increased by 2.5% in Japan, 5.6%
	in North America, 2.8% in Europe and 3.3% in Other, and would have decreased by 2.6% in Asia compared with the prior fiscal year.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	61
</FONT>
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Net revenues in Japan increased due primarily to the effect of changes in exchange rates related to
	export transactions, despite Toyota&#146;s domestic and exported vehicle unit sales decreasing by 120&nbsp;thousand vehicles compared with the prior fiscal year. For fiscal 2015 and 2016, exported vehicle unit sales were 1,784 thousand units and
	1,759 thousand units, respectively.
</FONT>
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Net revenues in North America increased due primarily to the 124&nbsp;thousand vehicles increase in
	vehicle unit sales compared with the prior fiscal year. The vehicle unit sales increased due mainly to the market progressing in a steady manner and strong sales of the RAV4, NX and other car models.
</FONT>
</P>

	62

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Net revenues in Europe decreased due primarily to the 15&nbsp;thousand vehicles decrease in vehicle unit
	sales compared with the prior fiscal year. The vehicle unit sales decreased due mainly to decreased sales in Russia, despite the strong sales in Western Europe, especially in France and Spain.
</FONT>
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Net revenues in Asia increased due primarily to the favorable impact of fluctuations in foreign currency
	translation rates despite the vehicle unit sales decreasing by 144 thousand compared with the prior fiscal year. The decrease in vehicle unit sales was due mainly to decreased sales in Indonesia and Thailand, which in turn was attributable mainly to
	the downturn of the market and intensifying competitive market conditions.
</FONT>
</P>

<A NAME="eolPage69"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D19734D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Net revenues in Other decreased due primarily to the 161 thousand vehicles decrease in
	vehicle unit sales compared with the prior fiscal year. The decrease in vehicle unit sales was due mainly to decreased sales in the Middle East, Africa and Central and South America.
</FONT>
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Operating costs and expenses increased by &yen;1,065.1 billion, or 4.4%, to &yen;25,549.1 billion during
	fiscal 2016 compared with the prior fiscal year. This increase resulted from the &yen;510.0 billion impact of changes in vehicle unit sales and sales mix, &yen;350.7 billion unfavorable impact of fluctuations in foreign currency translation rates,
	&yen;161.0 billion increase in cost of financing operations (excluding the effect of fluctuation in foreign currency translation rates) and the &yen;433.4 billion increase of miscellaneous costs and others, partially offset by the &yen;390.0 billion
	impact of cost reduction efforts.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The increase in miscellaneous costs and others was due mainly to the &yen;110.0 billion
	increase in labor costs, the &yen;50.0 billion increase in research and development expenses, the &yen;50.0 billion increase in depreciation expenses and the &yen;130.0 billion increase in other various costs, partially offset by the &yen;62.8
	billion decrease in product quality related expenses.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The decrease in product quality related expenses was due mainly to the
	effect of the strengthening of the Japanese yen against other currencies at the end of fiscal 2016 in comparison to the prior fiscal year end, primarily concerning the translation of liabilities denominated in foreign currencies. See note 13 to the
	consolidated financial statements for further discussion.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	During fiscal 2016 and beyond, Toyota announced recalls and other
	safety measures including the following:
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	In October 2015, Toyota announced in Japan and other regions recalls on certain
	Toyota vehicles in relation to the power window master switch. In November 2015, Toyota announced in Japan and other regions recalls on certain Toyota vehicles in relation to the clutch piston in the continuously variable transmission. In May, June,
	August, September and November 2015 and in March, May and June 2016, Toyota announced in Japan and other regions recalls on certain Toyota and Lexus vehicles in relation to the driver/front passenger airbag inflator.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	64
</FONT>
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage70"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D19734D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<I>
	Cost Reduction Efforts
</I>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	During fiscal 2016, continued cost reduction efforts together with suppliers contributed to a reduction of operating costs and expenses by &yen;390.0 billion. This was due to &yen;340.0 billion in cost
	reduction efforts concerning design related costs due mainly to ongoing value engineering activities, and &yen;50.0 billion in cost reduction efforts at plants and logistics departments.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	These cost reduction efforts related to ongoing value engineering and value analysis activities, the use of common parts resulting in a
	reduction of part types and other manufacturing initiatives designed to reduce the costs of vehicle production. The amount of the effect of cost reduction efforts includes the impact of fluctuation in the price of steel, precious metals, non-ferrous
	alloys including aluminum, plastic parts and other production materials and parts.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<I>
	Cost of Products Sold
</I>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Cost of products sold increased by &yen;539.7 billion, or 2.6%, to &yen;21,456.0 billion during fiscal 2016 compared with the prior fiscal
	year. The increase resulted mainly from the &yen;450.0 billion impact of changes in vehicle unit sales and sales mix, the &yen;252.2 billion unfavorable impact of fluctuations in foreign currency translation rates, the &yen;60.0 billion increase in
	labor costs and the &yen;50.0 billion increase in research and development expenses, partially offset by the &yen;390.0 billion impact of cost reduction efforts.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<I>
	Cost of Financing Operations
</I>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Cost of financing operations increased by
	&yen;224.0 billion, or 24.2%, to &yen;1,149.3 billion during fiscal 2016 compared with the prior fiscal year. The increase resulted mainly from the increase in depreciation expenses, which was mostly attributable to an increase in operating leases.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<I>
	Selling, General and Administrative Expenses
</I>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Selling, general and administrative expenses increased by &yen;301.4 billion, or 11.4%, to &yen;2,943.6 billion during fiscal 2016 compared with the prior fiscal year. This increase mainly reflected the
	&yen;60.0 billion impact of changes in vehicle unit sales and sales mix, the &yen;53.8 billion increase in advertising costs, the &yen;50.0 billion increase in labor costs, the &yen;35.4 billion unfavorable impact of fluctuations in foreign currency
	translation rates and the increase in other various costs.
</FONT>
</P>
<EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<A NAME="FIS_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE_29"></A>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	Operating Income
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE CELLSPACING="0" CELLPADDING="0" WIDTH="100%" BORDER="0" STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" ALIGN="CENTER">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="83%">
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" WIDTH="9%">
</TD>
<TD>
</TD>
<TD>
</TD>
<TD>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" COLSPAN="2" ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="BORDER-BOTTOM:1PX SOLID #000000">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="1">
<B>
	Yen&nbsp;in&nbsp;millions
</B>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Toyota&#146;s operating income increased by &yen;103.4 billion, or 3.8%, to &yen;2,853.9 billion during
	fiscal 2016 compared with the prior fiscal year. This increase was due mainly to the &yen;390.0 billion impact of cost reduction efforts and the &yen;160.0 billion favorable impact of changes in foreign currency exchange rates, partially offset by
	the &yen;120.0 billion impact of marketing activities, and the &yen;340.0 billion increase in miscellaneous costs and
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	65
</FONT>
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage71"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D19734D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	others. The increase in miscellaneous costs and others was due to the &yen;110.0 billion increase in labor costs, the &yen;50.0 billion increase in research and development expenses, the
	&yen;50.0 billion increase in depreciation expenses and the &yen;130.0 billion increase in other various costs.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Marketing
	activities and marketing efforts include changes in vehicle unit sales and sales mix, sales expenses and other.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	During fiscal
	2016, operating income (before elimination of intersegment profits) compared with the prior fiscal year increased by &yen;106.0 billion, or 6.7%, in Japan, and &yen;27.4 billion, or 6.5%, in Asia, whereas it decreased by &yen;55.7 billion, or 9.5%,
	in North America, &yen;8.7 billion, or 10.7%, in Europe, and &yen;2.6 billion, or 2.3%, in Other.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The following is a
	description of operating income in each geographic market.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<I>
	Japan
</I>
</FONT>
</P>

	&nbsp;

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	Other Income and Expenses
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Interest and dividend income increased by &yen;10.7 billion, or 7.3%, to &yen;157.8 billion during fiscal 2016 compared with the prior fiscal year.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Interest expense increased by &yen;12.5 billion, or 54.8%, to &yen;35.4 billion during fiscal 2016 compared with the prior fiscal year.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Foreign exchange gain (loss), net decreased by &yen;93.7 billion to a loss of &yen;5.5 billion during fiscal 2016 compared
	with the prior fiscal year. Foreign exchange gains and losses include the differences between the value of foreign currency denominated assets and liabilities recognized through transactions in foreign currencies translated at prevailing exchange
	rates and the value at the date the transaction settled during the fiscal year, including those settled using forward foreign currency exchange contracts, or the value translated by appropriate year-end exchange rates. The &yen;93.7 billion decrease
	in foreign exchange gain (loss), net was due mainly to the gains recorded in fiscal 2015 resulting from the Japanese yen being weaker against foreign currencies at the dates of settlement of the foreign currency trade accounts receivable than at the
	dates of the transactions.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Other income, net increased by &yen;82.6 billion to &yen;12.5 billion during fiscal 2016 compared
	with the prior fiscal year. The increase was due mainly to the effect of the reissuance of treasury stock for Toyota Mobility Foundation, a General Incorporated Foundation, being recorded in the prior fiscal year. See note 17 to the consolidated
	financial statements for further discussion.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	Income Taxes
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The provision for income taxes decreased by &yen;15.2 billion, or 1.7%, to &yen;878.2 billion during fiscal 2016 compared with the prior
	fiscal year due mainly to the reduction of the corporation tax rate resulting from fiscal
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	67
</FONT>
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage73"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D19734D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	2015 Japanese tax reforms. The effective tax rate for fiscal 2016 was 29.4%, which was lower than the statutory tax rate in Japan. This was due mainly to the increase in tax credits and the
	effect of foreign subsidiaries where statutory tax rates are lower than that of Japan.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	Net Income Attributable to Noncontrolling
	Interests and Equity in Earnings of Affiliated Companies
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Net income attributable to noncontrolling interests decreased
	by &yen;13.0 billion, or 9.7%, to &yen;121.5 billion during fiscal 2016 compared with the prior fiscal year. This was due mainly to a decrease during fiscal 2016 in net income attributable to the shareholders of consolidated subsidiaries.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Equity in earnings of affiliated companies during fiscal 2016 increased by &yen;20.5 billion, or 6.7%, to
	&yen;329.0&nbsp;billion compared with the prior fiscal year. This increase was due mainly to an increase during fiscal 2016 in net income attributable to the shareholders of affiliated companies accounted for by the equity method.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	Net Income Attributable to Toyota Motor Corporation
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Net income attributable to the shareholders of Toyota Motor Corporation increased by &yen;139.3 billion, or 6.4%, to &yen;2,312.6 billion during fiscal 2016 compared with the prior fiscal year.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Net income attributable to common shareholders during fiscal 2016 is &yen;2,306.6 billion, which is derived by deducting
	dividends and accretion to Model AA Class Shares of &yen;6.0 billion from net income attributable to Toyota Motor Corporation.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	Other
	Comprehensive Income and Loss
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Other comprehensive income and loss decreased by &yen;1,816.1 billion to a loss of
	&yen;866.7 billion for fiscal 2016 compared with the prior fiscal year. This decrease resulted from unrealized holding losses on securities in fiscal 2016 of &yen;302.6&nbsp;billion compared with gains of &yen;567.0 billion in the prior fiscal year
	due mainly to a decrease in prices of marketable securities in stock exchange markets in Japan, from unfavorable foreign currency translation adjustment losses of &yen;362.9 billion in fiscal 2016 compared with gains of &yen;380.4 billion in the
	prior fiscal year due mainly to appreciation of the yen against the U.S. dollar, and from pension liability adjustment losses in fiscal 2016 of &yen;201.1 billion compared with gains of &yen;1.9 billion in the prior fiscal year due mainly to an
	increase in pension obligations resulting from decreasing discount rates in Japan and a decrease in fair value of plan assets.
</FONT>
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	68
</FONT>
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage74"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D19734D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<I>
	Automotive Operations Segment
</I>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The automotive operations segment is Toyota&#146;s largest operating segment by net revenues. Net revenues for the automotive segment
	increased during fiscal 2016 by &yen;915.2 billion, or 3.7%, to &yen;25,977.4&nbsp;billion compared with the prior fiscal year. The increase mainly reflects the &yen;330.0 billion favorable impact of changes in vehicle unit sales and sales mix and
	the &yen;307.5 billion favorable impact of fluctuations in foreign currency translation rates.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Operating income from the
	automotive operations increased by &yen;123.6 billion, or 5.3%, to &yen;2,448.9&nbsp;billion during fiscal 2016 compared with the prior fiscal year. This increase in operating income was due mainly to the &yen;390.0 billion impact of cost reduction
	efforts and the &yen;160.0 billion favorable impact of changes in foreign currency exchange rates, partially offset by the &yen;110.0 billion impact of marketing activities and the &yen;340.0&nbsp;billion increase in miscellaneous costs and others.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The impact of marketing activities was due primarily to the decrease in Toyota&#146;s vehicle unit sales by 291&nbsp;thousand
	vehicles compared with the prior fiscal year. The vehicle unit sales decreased due mainly to the slowdown of the mini-vehicles market in Japan, the heating up of the competitive climate, as well as the market downturn, in Asia, the fall in demand
	resulting from the low price of crude oil and currency weakness in the Middle East, Africa, and Central and South America despite the increase in sales in the steady North American market. The increase in miscellaneous costs and others was due
	mainly to the &yen;110.0&nbsp;billion increase in labor costs, the &yen;50.0 billion increase in research and development expenses, the &yen;50.0&nbsp;billion increase in depreciation expenses and the &yen;110.0 billion increase in other various
	costs.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<I>
	Financial Services Operations Segment
</I>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Net revenues for the financial services operations increased during fiscal 2016 by &yen;235.0 billion, or 14.2%, to &yen;1,896.2 billion compared with the prior fiscal year. This increase was primarily
	due to the &yen;74.8 billion favorable impact of fluctuations in foreign currency translation rates.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Operating income from
	financial services operations decreased by &yen;22.6 billion, or 6.2%, to &yen;339.2 billion during fiscal 2016 compared with the prior fiscal year. This decrease was due primarily to a &yen;19.7&nbsp;billion worsening overall of valuation gains or
	losses on interest rate swaps stated at fair value, mainly in North America.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<I>
	All Other Operations Segment
</I>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Net revenues for Toyota&#146;s other operations segments decreased by &yen;78.4 billion, or 6.2%, to &yen;1,177.3&nbsp;billion during
	fiscal 2016 compared with the prior fiscal year.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Operating income from Toyota&#146;s other operations segments increased by
	&yen;0.8 billion, or 1.3%, to &yen;66.5&nbsp;billion during fiscal 2016 compared with the prior fiscal year.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	69
</FONT>
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage75"></A>

<TR>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	*
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#147;Other&#148; consists of Central and South America, Oceania, Africa and the Middle East.
</FONT>

</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	Net Revenues
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Toyota had net revenues for fiscal 2015 of
	&yen;27,234.5 billion, an increase of &yen;1,542.6 billion, or 6.0%, compared with the prior fiscal year. This increase mainly reflected the favorable impact of fluctuations in foreign currency translation rates of &yen;962.2 billion and changes in
	vehicle unit sales and sales mix of &yen;360.0 billion. Excluding the impact of changes in the Japanese yen values used for translation purposes of &yen;962.2 billion, net revenues would have been &yen;26,272.2 billion during fiscal 2015, a 2.3%
	increase compared with the prior fiscal year. The North America automotive market in calendar year 2014 increased by 5.8% compared with the prior calendar year due to the market in the U.S. progressing in a steady manner. However the Japanese
	automotive market in fiscal 2015 decreased by 8.9% compared with the prior fiscal year due to the market downturn resulting from the consumption tax increase. Under these automotive market conditions, Toyota&#146;s consolidated vehicle unit sales
	decreased by 1.6% compared with the prior fiscal year to 8,972&nbsp;thousand vehicles.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	70
</FONT>
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Toyota&#146;s net revenues include net revenues from sales of products, consisting of net revenues from
	automotive operations and all other operations, which increased by 5.3% during fiscal 2015 compared with the prior fiscal year to &yen;25,612.8 billion, and net revenues from financial services operations which increased by 17.6% during fiscal 2015
	compared with the prior fiscal year to &yen;1,621.6 billion. Excluding the impact of changes in the Japanese yen values used for translation purposes of &yen;864.5 billion, net revenues from sales of products would have been &yen;24,748.2 billion
	during fiscal 2015, a 1.8% increase compared with the prior fiscal year. The increase in net revenues from sales of products is mainly due to changes in vehicle unit sales and sales mix. Excluding the impact of changes in the Japanese yen values
	used for translation purposes of &yen;97.7 billion, net revenues from financial services operations would have been &yen;1,523.9 billion during fiscal 2015, a 10.5% increase compared with the prior fiscal year.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The following table shows the number of financing contracts by geographic region at the end of fiscal 2015 and 2014, respectively.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
	&nbsp;

	*
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#147;Other&#148; consists of Central and South America, Oceania and Africa.
</FONT>

</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Geographically, net revenues (before the elimination of intersegment revenues) for fiscal 2015 increased by 0.7% in Japan, 19.2% in North America, 4.5% in Europe, 2.1% in Asia, and 4.8% in Other compared
	with the prior fiscal year. Excluding the impact of changes in the Japanese yen values used for translation purposes of &yen;962.2 billion, net revenues in fiscal 2015 would have increased by 0.7% in Japan, 9.5% in North America, 4.4% in Europe and
	7.2% in Other compared with the prior fiscal year, and would have decreased by 3.7% in Asia compared with the prior fiscal year.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	71
</FONT>
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Net revenues in Japan increased due primarily to the effect of changes in exchange rates related to
	export transactions, despite Toyota&#146;s domestic and exported vehicle unit sales decreasing by 282&nbsp;thousand vehicles compared with the prior fiscal year. For fiscal 2014 and 2015, exported vehicle unit sales were 1,854 thousand units and
	1,784 thousand units, respectively.
</FONT>
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Net revenues in North America increased due primarily to the favorable effect of fluctuations of currency
	translation rates to the Japanese yen, and the 186&nbsp;thousand vehicles increase in vehicle unit sales compared with the prior fiscal year. The vehicle unit sales increased due mainly to the market progressing in a steady manner and strong sales
	of the Corolla, RAV4 and other car models.
</FONT>
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Net revenues in Europe increased due primarily to the 15&nbsp;thousand vehicles increase in vehicle unit
	sales compared with the prior fiscal year. The vehicle unit sales increased due mainly to the strong sales in Western Europe, especially in Italy and the United Kingdom.
</FONT>
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Net revenues in Asia increased due primarily to the favorable impact of fluctuations in foreign currency
	translation rates despite the vehicle unit sales decreasing by 120 thousand compared with the prior fiscal year. The decrease in vehicle unit sales was due mainly to decreased sales in Thailand and Indonesia, which in turn was attributable mainly to
	the shrinking of the market and competitive market conditions.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	73
</FONT>
</P>

	Net revenues in Other increased due primarily to the changes in vehicle sales mix despite vehicle unit
	sales decreasing by 14 thousand vehicles compared with the prior fiscal year.
